title: The Silk Road: Connecting the ancient world through trade - Shannon Harris Castelo

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the Silk Road?

options.label: A
options.text: To facilitate the exchange of goods and ideas between cultures

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a single, unified empire across Eurasia

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the spread of a single religion or ideology

options.label: D
options.text: To enable the movement of people from one region to another

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following civilizations was NOT directly connected to the Scythians?
What was the significance of the Persian Royal Road?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the longest road in the ancient world

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first road to connect East Asia with the West

options.label: C
options.text: It allowed goods and messages to travel at nearly 1/10 the time it would take a single traveler

options.label: D
options.text: It was built by Alexander the Great

multiple-choice.question: Who was the ambassador who played a key role in establishing trade relations between China and the West?
What was one of the consequences of the Roman Empire's trade with China?

options.label: A
options.text: An influx of gold into Rome

options.label: B
options.text: An outflow of gold from Rome

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of Christianity to China

options.label: D
options.text: The adoption of Chinese customs in Rome

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following technologies was possibly transmitted from China to the Western world through the Silk Road?
What was the impact of the Mongolian hordes on the Silk Road?

options.label: A
options.text: They disrupted trade routes and caused a decline in cultural exchange

options.label: B
options.text: They actively protected trade routes and facilitated cultural exchange

options.label: C
options.text: They had no significant impact on the Silk Road

options.label: D
options.text: They only traded with China and not with other regions

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of the movement of traditions and innovations through the Silk Road?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of Buddhism from India to China and Japan

options.label: B
options.text: The adoption of Greek customs in Egypt

options.label: C
options.text: The transmission of Roman law to China

options.label: D
options.text: The spread of Christianity to India

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the factors that contributed to the decline of the Silk Road?

options.label: C
options.text: The withdrawal of China from international trade

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the transcript regarding globalization?

options.label: A
options.text: Globalization is a new phenomenon that has only emerged in recent centuries

options.label: B
options.text: Globalization has its benefits, but it also has significant drawbacks

options.label: C
options.text: Globalization is not a new phenomenon, but rather has its roots in ancient trade networks like the Silk Road

options.label: D
options.text: Globalization is only possible through the use of modern technologies like the internet and airplanes

title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is pain defined as in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage

options.label: C
options.text: A cognitive function that helps us focus

multiple-choice.question: How do nociceptors respond to tissue damage?

options.label: A
options.text: They release endorphins to reduce pain

options.label: B
options.text: They fire and send signals to the spinal cord and brain

options.label: C
options.text: They activate the salience network to ignore pain

options.label: D
options.text: They stimulate the modulation network to increase pain

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the salience network in the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: To decide what to pay attention to

options.label: C
options.text: To activate motor pathways for physical response

options.label: D
options.text: To release endorphins for pain relief

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people experience greater pain than others?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to differences in pain sensitivity and efficacy of brain circuits

options.label: B
options.text: Because of differences in physical strength and endurance

options.label: C
options.text: Due to variations in emotional response to pain

options.label: D
options.text: Because of differences in cognitive function

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of personalized medicine in pain treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a single treatment that works for everyone

options.label: B
options.text: To tailor treatments to individual patients based on their brain responses to pain

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the use of pain medications

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the use of alternative therapies

multiple-choice.question: How do some people cope with pain using distraction?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing on the pain to overcome it

options.label: B
options.text: By using tasks to distract themselves from pain

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the pain and doing nothing

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the modulation network in the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: To decide what to pay attention to

options.label: C
options.text: To activate motor pathways for physical response

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to understand individual variability in pain brain circuits?

options.label: A
options.text: So that a single treatment can be developed for everyone

options.label: B
options.text: So that treatments can be tailored to individual patients

options.label: C
options.text: So that pain can be eliminated completely

options.label: D
options.text: So that pain medications can be reduced

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a treatment that can be used for mild pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescription medications that target specific pain-sensing circuits

options.label: B
options.text: Non-prescription medications that act on cells where pain signals start

options.label: C
options.text: Alternative therapies like meditation and yoga

multiple-choice.question: What tool can be used to map brain pathways and tailor treatments to individual patients?

title: How languages evolve - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the biblical story that tells the tale of humanity speaking a single language before splitting into many groups?

options.label: A
options.text: The Story of Adam and Eve

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the development of different languages according to the transcript?

Why is it difficult to determine the exact number of languages spoken worldwide?

If two languages have similar sounding words, what does this necessarily indicate about their relationship?

options.label: C
options.text: They may be related, but it's not conclusive

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge linguists face when constructing language family trees?

options.label: A
options.text: Deciding where the branches at the bottom should end

multiple-choice.question: What can linguistics reveal about ancient peoples?
Why may it be impossible to determine how language came about or whether all human languages had a common ancestor?

title: A digital reimagining of Gettysburg - Anne Knowles

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Confederate general who made crucial mistakes during the Battle of Gettysburg?
What does GIS stand for?

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of GK Warren's observation from Little Roundtop?

multiple-choice.question: Who inspired the speaker to try 30-day challenges?

What was one of the benefits the speaker noticed while doing 30-day challenges?

options.label: D
options.text: He lost interest in new activities

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's strategy for completing his novel in 30 days?

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker learn about making changes in his life?

options.label: A
options.text: Big changes are more likely to stick

options.label: B
options.text: Small changes are less likely to stick

options.label: C
options.text: Small sustainable changes are more likely to stick

options.label: D
options.text: No changes are likely to stick

options.label: A
options.text: He continued to abstain from sugar

options.label: B
options.text: He went back to consuming sugar on day 31

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea the speaker is trying to convey?

options.label: B
options.text: 30-day challenges are only for adventurous people

options.label: C
options.text: Anyone can try something new for 30 days

options.label: D
options.text: 30-day challenges are a waste of time

options.label: B

title: Why good leaders make you feel safe - Simon Sinek

multiple-choice.question: What award was Captain William Swenson recently awarded for his actions on September 8, 2009?
According to the speaker, what motivates people to put themselves and their lives at risk to save others?

options.label: C
options.text: A deep sense of trust and cooperation

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A social construct where individuals feel safe and protected within a group

options.label: C
options.text: A leadership strategy to motivate employees

options.label: D
options.text: A business model to increase productivity

options.label: B
options.text: To maximize profits and achieve business goals

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain authority and control over employees

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Because they are not effective leaders

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: They become more competitive and individualistic

options.label: C
options.text: They trust and cooperate with each other

options.label: D
options.text: They become more fearful and anxious

options.label: A
options.text: A rank or position of authority

options.label: B
options.text: A choice to prioritize the safety and lives of others

options.label: C
options.text: A skill that can be learned through training

options.label: D
options.text: A trait that some people are born with

title: How the heart actually pumps blood - Edmond Hui

multiple-choice.question: What was the historical understanding of the heart's purpose in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: It was well understood to pump blood throughout the body.

options.label: B
options.text: It was thought to be a simple organ with no major function.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a mystery, and even prominent figures like Leonardo da Vinci were confused by it.

options.label: D
options.text: It was considered a secondary organ, not vital to human survival.

multiple-choice.question: Why was it difficult to understand the heart's function through observation?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart is a very small organ.

options.label: B
options.text: The blood vessels are transparent, making it hard to see the blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: The body would perish quickly if the heart was exposed or taken out, and the blood itself is opaque.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart valves are very complex and hard to comprehend.

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct description of blood circulation in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: Dual-circulation, with one loop to the lungs and back, and another to the body and back.

options.label: B
options.text: Figure-eight circulation, with blood going from one heart pump to the lungs, back to the second heart pump, and then to the body.

options.label: C
options.text: Single-circulation, with blood going from the heart to the body and back.

options.label: D
options.text: Triple-circulation, with three separate loops for the lungs, body, and brain.

multiple-choice.question: Why do many students struggle to understand the heart's function in biology lessons?

options.label: A
options.text: The subject is too simple and not engaging.

options.label: B
options.text: The diagrams and models used to teach the subject are too complex.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart's function is often not demonstrated clearly, leading to superficial understanding.

options.label: D
options.text: The subject is not taught in schools.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of cutting off the atria and trimming them down to the tops of the ventricles in the experiment described?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the heart look more complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: To remove the incoming veins attached to the atria and simplify the heart's appearance.

options.label: C
options.text: To stop the heart from pumping water.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when water is run into the right ventricle from a tap in the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The ventricular valve stays open, and water flows freely.

options.label: B
options.text: The ventricular valve tries to close against the incoming stream, and the ventricle inflates with water.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart starts to beat on its own.

multiple-choice.question: What can be observed when the ventricle is squeezed in the experiment?

options.label: B
options.text: The ventricular valves close against each other, and a stream of water squirts out of the pulmonary artery.

options.label: D
options.text: The atria start to fill with water.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the ventricular valves show little wear and tear over time?

options.label: A
options.text: They are made of a very durable material.

options.label: C
options.text: They close against each other with very little friction.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used very often.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of beats a heart gives in its lifetime?
What is the benefit of understanding how the heart works, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps you to become a better medic.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows you to appreciate the complexity of the human body.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives new resonance to the feeling you get when you experience strong emotions or physical sensations.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps you to live a longer life.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To represent the internal distribution of a population and make predictions about future trends

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: How does the woman's story relate to the concept of mindfulness in speech?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.text: To create a copy of the DNA instructions

options.text: To display the warning signal on the cell membrane

options.label: B
options.text: To produce energy for the cell

options.label: C
options.text: To control the movement of materials in and out of the cell

options.text: To display warning signals on the cell membrane

title: History vs. Vladimir Lenin - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was Vladimir Lenin's role in the overthrow of the Russian tsar Nicholas II in 1917?

options.label: A
options.text: He led the February 1917 uprisings that forced the tsar to abdicate.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a key figure in the Duma that formed a provisional government after the tsar's abdication.

options.label: C
options.text: He returned to Russia in April 1917 and instigated riots against the provisional government.

options.label: D
options.text: He was still exiled in Switzerland during the February 1917 uprisings.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the Russian workers' dissatisfaction with the tsar's rule?

options.label: A
options.text: The tsar's refusal to abolish serfdom.

options.label: B
options.text: The factory bosses' treatment of the workers and low wages.

options.label: C
options.text: The tsar's involvement in World War I.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of a constitution and elected parliament.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the tsar's attempts to introduce reforms in 1905?

options.label: A
options.text: The reforms were successful, and the rebellion was ended.

options.label: B
options.text: The reforms failed, and the rebellion continued.

options.label: C
options.text: The tsar introduced a constitution and an elected parliament but retained absolute power.

options.label: D
options.text: The tsar was overthrown, and a new government was established.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Lenin's government execute the tsar's entire family, including the children?

options.label: A
options.text: To avenge the tsar's past repression and executions.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent any royal heir from being recognized as ruler by foreign governments.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a new socialist order and eliminate the old aristocracy.

options.label: D
options.text: To punish the tsar's family for their involvement in World War I.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Lenin's efforts to establish a socialist order in Russia?

options.label: A
options.text: A modern, industrial superpower with a well-educated population and unprecedented opportunities for women.

options.label: B
options.text: A totalitarian regime with widespread repression, famines, and millions executed or sent to die in camps.

options.label: C
options.text: A constitutional social democratic government with a strong economy and high standard of living.

options.label: D
options.text: A failed state with a collapsed economy and widespread poverty.

multiple-choice.question: How did Lenin's government respond to the Tambov Rebellion, where peasants resisted grain confiscation?

options.label: A
options.text: By negotiating with the peasants and addressing their grievances.

options.label: B
options.text: By sending the army to crush the rebellion and using poison gas to kill the peasants.

options.label: C
options.text: By introducing reforms to improve the peasants' living conditions and reduce grain confiscation.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the rebellion and focusing on other issues.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Bolsheviks' rise to power in October 1917?

options.label: A
options.text: A peaceful transfer of power, with the provisional government stepping down voluntarily.

options.label: B
options.text: A violent coup, with the Bolsheviks seizing power by force.

options.label: C
options.text: A negotiated settlement, with the Bolsheviks and the provisional government sharing power.

options.label: D
options.text: A temporary coalition government, with the Bolsheviks and other socialist parties working together.

multiple-choice.question: How did Lenin's government treat other socialist and anarchist parties after gaining power?

options.label: A
options.text: They formed alliances and worked together to establish a socialist order.

options.label: B
options.text: They tolerated them and allowed them to operate freely.

options.label: C
options.text: They suppressed them and executed their leaders.

options.label: D
options.text: They ignored them and focused on other issues.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Stalin's rise to power after Lenin's death?

options.label: A
options.text: A more democratic and liberal government, with greater freedoms and opportunities for the people.

options.label: B
options.text: A continuation of Lenin's policies, with a focus on establishing a socialist order.

options.label: C
options.text: A cult of personality and absolute power, with widespread repression and executions.

options.label: D
options.text: A period of economic stagnation and decline, with a decrease in living standards.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument in favor of putting historical figures like Lenin on trial?

options.label: A
options.text: To punish them for their past mistakes and wrongdoing.

options.label: B
options.text: To learn from their experiences and avoid repeating the mistakes of the past.

options.label: C
options.text: To rehabilitate their reputations and restore their honor.

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a particular ideology or agenda.

title: What is Alzheimer's disease? - Ivan Seah Yu Jun

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the clumping of beta-amyloid proteins in Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Blockage of signaling and immune reactions

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure the tubes in the nerve cells are straight

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To train the body's immune system to attack beta-amyloid plaques

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of Alzheimer's disease on the production of acetylcholine?

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the production of beta-amyloid proteins

title: Grammar's great divide: The Oxford comma - TED-Ed

options.text: It is only used in creative writing

options.label: C

options.text: That his legacy is complex and open to interpretation

options.label: D
options.text: That he was a product of his time and should not be judged by modern standards
